docs.lead_paragraph: JACKY RUETTE was a sailor long before he was a restaurateur. You might say he has the sea in his blood. He was born in Le Havre, one of France's major seaports. His father and both his grandfathers were sailors, and he first went to sea in 1955 on the Liberte when he was 15 years old. Today, as the owner of La Petite Marmite restaurant on Mitchell Place in Manhattan, his sailing is strictly recreational, on a 30-foot Pearson that he docks at Young's Boatyard in Port of Egypt, near Greenport. Naturally, he dines very well on board. ''I do not want to be bothered with elaborate cooking on the weekends,'' he said, ''but I insist on good food.'' The hardships of a cramped, minimally equipped galley, limited storage space or rolling seas do not diminish the meals served on board the Clavier. The solution to these problems, according to Mr. Ruette, is to plan carefully, spend a little extra time during the week preparing food or shopping for ingredients that can be brought from home, and take advantage of the fresh local seafood and produce.

docs.lead_paragraph: On the second Saturday of every month, the importer Olé Olé Foods in Belleville opens its warehouse doors to the public and puts its stock of spices, artisanal olive oils and vinegars, sweets and other goods from Spain on sale. What ensues is a food fiesta.

docs.abstract: Molly O'Neill article on Vietnamese salads; recipes; photo (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: Everyday is salad day in vietnam. From the cool, mountainous north to the humid tropics of the south, there are two kinds of salad served but one national assumption: that a meal is not a meal without raw greens. Whenever you sit down to eat, in fact, a giant basket of leaves and herbs is brought to the table. These are used to season and wrap everything from spring rolls to grilled meat. So ubiquitous is this offering that it is not even recognized as a salad per se, but as a tenet of the table, as basic as flatware.

docs.lead_paragraph: IN THE THEATER WE CALL EACH other 'the kids,' " says La Chanze, "and 'the kids' know I like to cook." On free evenings, the young actress and a few friends often gather for a meal. "If they had a choice of sitting around or going out, they'd rather I cook," she says. Impromptu entertaining is the norm for La Chanze. Best known as Ti Moune in the Broadway musical "Once on This Island," which earned her a Tony nomination, she left the show last month to pursue other interests. She is looking ahead to her first film role in a production tentatively called "My New Gun," and plans to play the part of Mary Magdalene in "Jesus Christ Superstar" in Philadelphia. That will mean commuting from her home in New York.

byline.original: By OLWEN WOODIER; OLWEN WOODIER, who lives in Vienna, Va., writes regularly about food for The Times

docs.lead_paragraph: FOR Asian immigrants, Eden Center, a Vietnamese-operated shopping mall on Wilson Boulevard in Falls Church, Va., is a source of ingredients essential to their national cuisines; for non-Asians, the lure is the more than 20 Vietnamese restaurants in the area. Even visitors heading mainly for a restaurant, however, might enjoy a stop beforehand at the Eden Supermarket. Inviting examination are jars of curries and chili pastes, quart-size bottles of soy sauces ranging from black to mild, more than 300 kinds of teas, soup bowls and woks representing every Asian cuisine.

docs.lead_paragraph: Charles D. Colletti, publisher of Cuisine magazine, says that although the magazine is having trouble paying its current printing bill, it expects to be acquired by the end of the week. The magazine, which began in 1968 as Betty Crocker magazine, has a circulation of 750,000. Ad revenues for the first quarter, he says, are up 43 percent.

byline.original: By PATRICIA WELLS, Special to the New York Times

docs.lead_paragraph: Michel Guerard, the high priest of nouvelle cuisine, is experiencing a minor loss of faith: What was intended as a breath of fresh air, he says, is inducing claustrophobia. ''Today, everywhere you go in France, you find the same menus, the same dishes with even the same names, the same flavors,'' he said during an interview in his office on the Avenue de l'Opera. ''There is nothing original.'' When, a little more than a decade ago, Mr. Guerard and his fellow chefs Paul Bocuse, Alain Chapel and Jean and Pierre Troisgros popularized the idea of simpler, less rich French cooking, they started on the way to worldwide influence. Today nouvelle restaurants thrive all over France, Britain, West Germany and the United States. The food many of them serve, Mr. Guerard insists, lacks dignity, nobility, pride and nuance.
